verses.text: When the righteous triumph, there is great elation; but when the wicked rise to power, men go into hiding.

rsbNotes.title: Pr 28
rsbNotes.text: 28:1–28 This chapter contains a heavier concentration of theological reflection than earlier chapters of proverbial sentences. Sometimes this is explicit, with references to God or to the law and righteousness. In other sentences it is more implicit, as in the contrast of the righteous and the wicked, which seems to assume the underlying providential order and judgment of God.

rsbNotes.title: Pr 28:12
rsbNotes.text: 28:12 Righteousness leads to social order and happiness, while unrighteousness destroys and alienates (v. 28 and 29:2).

verses.text: He who conceals his sins does not prosper, but whoever confesses and renounces them finds mercy.

rsbNotes.title: Pr 28:13
rsbNotes.text: 28:13 The orderliness and well-being in one’s life is linked to an intensely personal relationship with God. Unconfessed sin is the ultimate disorder in life. Confession and repentance lead to a restoration of a right relationship with God, based on mercy (Ps. 32:1–4; 1 John 1:6–9). All other relationships depend on this.
